Topic.Title: If Icahn deal is on table, why not announce. it....

Message.Msg: Because Icahn's deal is less than the $24,400,000,000 currently offered. Nobody can beat that, so all these guys are trying to come up with an angle to allow them to control the company for less that 24.4 billion. Remember, there will be lots of angles, but no real offers.

Topic.Title: Buy out

Message.Msg: Has to compete with Ichan, Blackstone, and M. Dell/Microsoft. Should have stuck with his fruit company... guess they ran out of ideas and got beat around in the mobile market. $17- $21/ share all told.

Message.Title: New Offers will be $14.50 to $15 range
Message.Msg: Blackstone, the world’s biggest private-equity firm, outlined an offer valued at $13.65 to $14.50 a share, said one of the people, who asked not to be identified because the process is private. Icahn said he’d pay $15 a share, with a cap on the amount of cash used in the deal, two people said. See http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-03-24/dell-said-to-get-rival-buyout-bids-from-blackstone-icahn.html?cmpid=yhoo

Message.Title: Speculation of Monday's DELL opening price due to new bids?

Topic.Title: New Offers will be $14.50 to $15 range

Message.Msg: Icahn has a cap on the money he can spend, and Blackstone needs to sell part of the company ( that they don't own yet ) to finance their angle. It seems that nobody can come up with more than 24.4 billion to beat the current offer. Yes, the stock will open higher tomorrow. But when investors realize that all these clever angles don't equal a real offer, the price will drop rapidly. This looks like a good option play.

Message.Title: There's no rival bid, and Michael failed to get finaning

And Hurd just got a new job very recently. I think this all Wall Street ploy to sucker in retail investors . Wall Street loaded up on Dell shares ,now the bid failed to get financing they want to unload.

Topic.Title: There's no rival bid, and Michael failed to get finaning

Message.Msg: Rival bid deadline was Saturday. They were going to make a bid you'd hear it long before deadline passed. The minute market closed Friday they let out this rival bid news. This whole thing is a farce.

Topic.Title: Speculation of Monday's DELL opening price due to new bids?
Speculation of Monday's DELL opening price due to new bids?

Message.Msg: I think it stays unchanged or goes down. According to the WSJ, neither of the bids tops $15. The typical haircut for an accepted buyout offer - one that won't be topped - is initially 6%, which reflects the uncertainty of financing and regulatory approval. A $15 bid implies a stock price of $14.10. I'm long April $14 calls, bought, as they say, as a "lottery ticket" for 13 to 19 cents a few weeks back. If it goes up, great, if it stays a little over $14, I'm about even.

Message.Title: Dell made 2,650,000 and HPQ lose 12,650,000. HPQ is trading at 22.00 so DELL should be worth more then

Topic.Title: Dell made 2,650,000 and HPQ lose 12,650,000. HPQ is trading at 22.00 so DELL should be worth more then

Message.Msg: And BAC made hundreds of times more, and it's only $12 ! What's up with that? Doesn't anyone know that a company's value is solely based on the price per share, and only the most recent quarter's earnings counts, even if there's seasonal variation? You tell 'em, dmrj!

Message.Title: Michael Dell to lose CEO job should BX or Icahn bids succeed in winning Dell Inc?
Message.Msg: Interesting that the WSJ and the other press outlets are suggesting that Mr Dell will be ousted, should the BX or Icahn bids win over Dell Inc. Trying to steal one's own company from the shareholders is likely to get more expensive in future. $15.50-to-$17 is the bid range for a win? Can Michael Dell and SL come up with a $18 bid? That is another $7.5 billion approx that will need to be raised. Why not just repatriate the funds lying overseas, pay the taxes on it and use that to fund the take out at $18?

Topic.Title: Michael Dell to lose CEO job should BX or Icahn bids succeed in winning Dell Inc?

Message.Msg: Deal won't get done unless Dell remains CEO and BOD retain seats, IMO. The board will likely decline even a $15 bid with those restrictions. Shareholders will probably agree, which makes a hostile takeover/proxy fight unlikely.

Topic.Title: Michael Dell to lose CEO job should BX or Icahn bids succeed in winning Dell Inc?

Message.Msg: They don't have to do anything. Blackstone's deal requires they sell a portion of the company ( that they don't own yet ) to finance their deal. That's because they can't come up with more than $24.4 B. Icahn will pay $15 per share, but only for 58% of the float according to reports. That's because .... ( you guessed it ) .... he can't come up with $24.4 either. Neither of these bids can beat the original offer. So the board can just ignore them.

Topic.Title: Speculation of Monday's DELL opening price due to new bids?

Message.Msg: Icahn is only offering $15 for 58% of the company. Now who do you think is going to be in that 58% - you retail shareholders, or the institutions? You'll own stock that, say, covers only Dell's consumer business, and will be back around $10.
